awd_titl_txt: Anti-Concentration, Random Matrices, and Random Functions
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of the project is to study problems concerning distribution of discrete random variables, such as random polynomials, random sums, and random matrices. These problems have many connections to other parts of mathematics, as well as applications in statistics and machine learning. 


The PI aims to  continue his development of a  theory of anti-concentration. This theory has found applications in various areas of mathematics, including probability, numercial linear algebra, and complexity theory. He will also investigate an old and natural problem of Erdos and Moser concerning sum-avoiding sets in the non-abelian setting, following his recent work with T. Tao concerning the abelian case. In another part of the proposal, the PI proposes to study  several problems concerning  random matrices and random functions. Many of these problems are very basic and easy to state, but have been major challenges to the mathematics community for a long time, and 
progress on them has been made very recently.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Computing roots and extremal points of a function is one of the most basic and improtant tasks in the whole mathematics, with applications in almost all brach of sciences. 

 

The question of how the roots and extremal points of a random function has a long and famous history, going back to studies of Littlewood-Offord and Kac almost 80 years ago. While the topic has been extensively studied since then, many natual and very basic questions are still open. For  instance, for most models of random functions, we do not know much about the limiting distribution of the number of real roots. 

 

The PI and his co-authors have obtained significant progresses concerning some of these questions. Among others, he established a central limit theorem for the number of real roots of  polynomials with random coeffcients having polynomial growth, generalizing a famous result in Mashlova,  obtained in the 1970s. He also proved that the same law applies for random Weyl functions. 

 

The PI and his co-authors obtained these results using a new approach of universality, which relies heavily on new anti-concentration estimates. This part of the project is of independent interest, and has been more and more frequently as a tool in many other studies, unrelated to random functions.
